title: Grounding LLM Reasoning with Knowledge Graphs
author: Alfonso Amayuelas (University of California, Santa Barbara), Joy Sain (JP Morgan Chase), Simerjot Kaur (JP Morgan Chase), Charese Smiley (JP Morgan Chase), ...
relevance_why: The integration of reasoning strategies with Knowledge Graphs (KGs) could enhance tasks related to audio-language modeling and content generation, helping to ground generative models in structured knowledge.
background: This paper explores how Large Language Models (LLMs) can improve their reasoning capabilities by leveraging Knowledge Graphs (KGs) to provide grounded reasoning processes.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework that integrates reasoning strategies with Knowledge Graphs during inference, achieving significant performance improvements on domain-specific question-answering tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) utilize discrete knowledge sources but often miss the relational complexities found in KGs.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by conducting reasoning in a stepwise manner that connects LLM outputs to KGs, navigating complex relationships more effectively.

key_innovation: Links each reasoning step of LLMs closely with KG data, enhancing accuracy and reliability in generating responses.
real_world_impact: This approach can improve the reliability of AI systems in critical domains, leading to better informed and accountable decision-making processes.
limitations: The performance highly depends on the quality of the knowledge encoded in the graph and may be constrained by computational resources.

new_terms.Knowledge Graph (KG): **A Knowledge Graph (KG)** is a structured representation of information where entities are nodes and relationships are edges, facilitating complex queries and reasoning.
new_terms.Chain-of-Thought (CoT): **Chain-of-Thought (CoT)** is a reasoning method that entails generating a sequence of logical steps where each step builds upon the previous ones to derive conclusions.
